Hi all,

 

Although this is way out of my field, based on inscriptions that claim
namban-tetsu use, I would push its introduction way past the late 16th cent.
The swords with such inscriptions are by smiths working in large residential
areas like Edo and Osaka. They are mainly late 17th and 18th century smiths.
I would think that the Dutch simply saw a lucrative market for iron ore and
began to import it through Dejima. We have all probably seen the photos of
the tear-shaped ingots that were imported for this use.

 

Gordon

Dear Excelsiorilluminati

Many thanks for the excellent research that you have done regarding 
the 'Die Liefke''s cannon, which seems to confirm our suspicions 
about these being of bronze. It is true, of course, that her 
cannonballs were almost certainly of cast iron; I believe that by 
the end of the C16 stone cannonballs had been virtually completely 
replaced by iron. It is thus possible that these might be considered 
as one possible source of namban iron.

Regards, John L.

the
